values.description:
An attempt to fix object deletion on exit, starting with Scene. 

The changes ensure that all references to a scene shared pointer are cleared and the scene destructor is called. 

Manually starting and quitting gazebo with an empty world confirmed this and I added a MainWindow test that verifies the shared pointer `use_count` just before exiting the test case.
values.title: Delete scene on exit

summary.raw:
An attempt to fix object deletion on exit, starting with Scene. 

The changes ensure that all references to a scene shared pointer are cleared and the scene destructor is called. 

Manually starting and quitting gazebo with an empty world confirmed this and I added a MainWindow test that verifies the shared pointer `use_count` just before exiting the test case.
summary.html:
An attempt to fix object deletion on exit, starting with Scene.

The changes ensure that all references to a scene shared pointer are cleared and the scene destructor is called.

Manually starting and quitting gazebo with an empty world confirmed this and I added a MainWindow test that verifies the shared pointer use_count just before exiting the test case.

values.description:
Based on the discussion [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1437/world-step-fails-to-solve-bilateral): 

when the denominator is numerically zero (absolute value  is less than `1e-16`, since there can be negative value), `1e-6` is added to the denominator, before doing the `dRecip` operation to get the reciprocal. 

A test world file  with default `cfm=0` named `revolute_joint_1437.world` is added [here](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/src/cfaadea331095a7843d5c4a59b03242ad340e09d/test/worlds/revolute_joint_1437.world?at=world_step_cfm_issue1437).  

I commented the message for user [here](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/src/cfaadea331095a7843d5c4a59b03242ad340e09d/deps/opende/src/lcp.cpp?at=world_step_cfm_issue1437#cl-538) and the other three places (search for `dRecip`), since they make the simulation too slow
values.title: fix the dRecip operation for when numerically denominator equals 0

summary.raw:
Based on the discussion [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1437/world-step-fails-to-solve-bilateral): 

when the denominator is numerically zero (absolute value  is less than `1e-16`, since there can be negative value), `1e-6` is added to the denominator, before doing the `dRecip` operation to get the reciprocal. 

A test world file  with default `cfm=0` named `revolute_joint_1437.world` is added [here](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/src/cfaadea331095a7843d5c4a59b03242ad340e09d/test/worlds/revolute_joint_1437.world?at=world_step_cfm_issue1437).  

I commented the message for user [here](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/gazebo/src/cfaadea331095a7843d5c4a59b03242ad340e09d/deps/opende/src/lcp.cpp?at=world_step_cfm_issue1437#cl-538) and the other three places (search for `dRecip`), since they make the simulation too slow
summary.html:
Based on the discussion here:

when the denominator is numerically zero (absolute value is less than 1e-16, since there can be negative value), 1e-6 is added to the denominator, before doing the dRecip operation to get the reciprocal.

A test world file with default cfm=0 named revolute_joint_1437.world is added here.

I commented the message for user here and the other three places (search for dRecip), since they make the simulation too slow

values.description:
To reproduce the problem:

1. You'll need dual monitors.
1. Remove your `~/.gazebo/gui.ini` file
1. Use handsim default and run the `arat_left.world`.
1. The GUI overlay should not appear, unless your stretch the window to span both monitors.

More info on [qt desktop](http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-4.8/qdesktopwidget.html).
values.title: Fix main window geometry. This will allow QT to report a correct window size

summary.raw:
To reproduce the problem:

1. You'll need dual monitors.
1. Remove your `~/.gazebo/gui.ini` file
1. Use handsim default and run the `arat_left.world`.
1. The GUI overlay should not appear, unless your stretch the window to span both monitors.

More info on [qt desktop](http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-4.8/qdesktopwidget.html).
summary.html:
To reproduce the problem:

  1. You'll need dual monitors.
  2. Remove your ~/.gazebo/gui.ini file
  3. Use handsim default and run the arat_left.world.
  4. The GUI overlay should not appear, unless your stretch the window to span both monitors.

More info on qt desktop.

values.description:
In case we ever switch to another message format like flatbuffers. The API is mostly agnostic already; this just gets rid of the `google::protobuf::` references in msgs.hh

* [trusty no gpu build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/38/) is clean
* [trusty nvidia build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/610/) has one unrelated failing test
values.title: Abstract message types so protobuf is not explicit in the msgs API

values.description:
There are [some warnings on Utopic](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_5.0-devel-utopic-amd64/38/warnings17Result/) and also [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/520/warnings7Result/) that we are using deprecated libavcodec functions (part of ffmpeg). This pull request creates helper functions with ifdefs that use the appropriate function for the given version of libavcodec (as recommended on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/24612042)). The homebrew jenkins build should show these warnings as fixed.

The functions were [deprecated here](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/d7b3ee9).
values.title: Fix ffmpeg deprecation warnings by creating helper functions with ifdefs

summary.raw:
There are [some warnings on Utopic](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_5.0-devel-utopic-amd64/38/warnings17Result/) and also [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/520/warnings7Result/) that we are using deprecated libavcodec functions (part of ffmpeg). This pull request creates helper functions with ifdefs that use the appropriate function for the given version of libavcodec (as recommended on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/24612042)). The homebrew jenkins build should show these warnings as fixed.

The functions were [deprecated here](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/d7b3ee9).
summary.html:
There are some warnings on Utopic and also homebrew that we are using deprecated libavcodec functions (part of ffmpeg). This pull request creates helper functions with ifdefs that use the appropriate function for the given version of libavcodec (as recommended on stackoverflow). The homebrew jenkins build should show these warnings as fixed.

The functions were deprecated here.

values.description:
Issue #1504

This pull request makes it so the model name is updated when the model is loaded into the editor. 

However, since the editor loads the SDF stored in the scene and doesn't look at the config file, the model name used will be the unique one for that session, which might still cause inconsistencies. For example:

1. Insert a `Cordless Drill`, then insert another `Cordless Drill`

1. Right-click the 2nd one and edit

1. In the editor, the name which shows on the palette is not `Cordless Drill` (from config), but `drill_0` (from the SDF, with a unique name)

1. Save & Exit, the model will appear in the Insert tab as `drill_0`

Not sure if this is enough to close the issue, but I think it's an improvement over always having `Untitled`. I think in the future when we start copying the whole model structure (meshes, materials, config), this issue should be revisited.
values.title: Model Editor: Keep model's name when loaded

summary.raw:
Issue #1504

This pull request makes it so the model name is updated when the model is loaded into the editor. 

However, since the editor loads the SDF stored in the scene and doesn't look at the config file, the model name used will be the unique one for that session, which might still cause inconsistencies. For example:

1. Insert a `Cordless Drill`, then insert another `Cordless Drill`

1. Right-click the 2nd one and edit

1. In the editor, the name which shows on the palette is not `Cordless Drill` (from config), but `drill_0` (from the SDF, with a unique name)

1. Save & Exit, the model will appear in the Insert tab as `drill_0`

Not sure if this is enough to close the issue, but I think it's an improvement over always having `Untitled`. I think in the future when we start copying the whole model structure (meshes, materials, config), this issue should be revisited.
summary.html:
Issue #1504

This pull request makes it so the model name is updated when the model is loaded into the editor.

However, since the editor loads the SDF stored in the scene and doesn't look at the config file, the model name used will be the unique one for that session, which might still cause inconsistencies. For example:

  1. Insert a Cordless Drill, then insert another Cordless Drill

  2. Right-click the 2nd one and edit

  3. In the editor, the name which shows on the palette is not Cordless Drill (from config), but drill_0 (from the SDF, with a unique name)

  4. Save & Exit, the model will appear in the Insert tab as drill_0

Not sure if this is enough to close the issue, but I think it's an improvement over always having Untitled. I think in the future when we start copying the whole model structure (meshes, materials, config), this issue should be revisited.

values.description:
There are [some warnings on Utopic](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-gazebo_5.0-devel-utopic-amd64/38/warnings17Result/) and also [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/520/warnings7Result/) that we are using deprecated libavcodec functions (part of ffmpeg). This pull request creates helper functions with ifdefs that use the appropriate function for the given version of libavcodec (as recommended on [stackoverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/24612042)). The homebrew jenkins build should show these warnings as fixed.

The functions were [deprecated here](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/d7b3ee9).

Previously submitted as pull request #1514, before it was actually working.

values.description:
this allows ConfigWidgets to parse and create widgets for configuring fields of enum type via a Qt combo box. 

Added a JointMsgWidget test in ConfigWidget_TEST that makes use of the new functions. Specifically   the joint `type` field is an enum in joint.proto. The test shows setting and getting joint type values (as well as testing and verifying all other joint fields).

The is needed later by a new joint inspector I am creating for model editor.
values.title: Supprt enum values in ConfigWidget

The is needed later by a new joint inspector I am creating for model editor.

this allows ConfigWidgets to parse and create widgets for configuring fields of enum type via a Qt combo box.

The is needed later by a new joint inspector I am creating for model editor.

values.description: The library `libstdc++` was the default c++ library on OS X 10.8 and earlier. As of 10.9, the default is `libc++`. In pull request #1171, `-lstdc++` was appended to the pkg-config flags on OS X. I think this can be removed, since it is out of date. The `EXAMPLE_*` tests compile for me without it.
values.title: Remove -lstdc++ from gazebo's pkg-config file on osx

summary.raw: The library `libstdc++` was the default c++ library on OS X 10.8 and earlier. As of 10.9, the default is `libc++`. In pull request #1171, `-lstdc++` was appended to the pkg-config flags on OS X. I think this can be removed, since it is out of date. The `EXAMPLE_*` tests compile for me without it.
summary.html: The library libstdc++ was the default c++ library on OS X 10.8 and earlier. As of 10.9, the default is libc++. In pull request #1171, -lstdc++ was appended to the pkg-config flags on OS X. I think this can be removed, since it is out of date. The EXAMPLE_* tests compile for me without it.

values.description:
Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules,
but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake.
As gazebo only considered the first one, `find_package(Gazebo)` failed
on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.
values.title: add path to OGRE's FindOGRE.cmake for non-Debian systems

summary.raw:
Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules,
but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake.
As gazebo only considered the first one, `find_package(Gazebo)` failed
on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.
summary.html: Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules, but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake. As gazebo only considered the first one, find_package(Gazebo) failed on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.

values.description:
If a physics engine parameter is not found in the physics engine implementation of `SetParam`, it calls `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`, which checks the parameter name against shared parameter keys such as `max_step_size` and `gravity`. New checks have been added to `ODEPhysics` and `BulletPhysics`.

I also fixed a mistake in one of my earlier PRs, which declared `bool ODEPhysics::GetParam` to private instead of public.

[Jenkins pending](build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/627/)
values.title: Call PhysicsEngine::SetParam in child physics engines

summary.raw:
If a physics engine parameter is not found in the physics engine implementation of `SetParam`, it calls `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`, which checks the parameter name against shared parameter keys such as `max_step_size` and `gravity`. New checks have been added to `ODEPhysics` and `BulletPhysics`.

I also fixed a mistake in one of my earlier PRs, which declared `bool ODEPhysics::GetParam` to private instead of public.

[Jenkins pending](build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/627/)
summary.html:
If a physics engine parameter is not found in the physics engine implementation of SetParam, it calls PhysicsEngine::SetParam, which checks the parameter name against shared parameter keys such as max_step_size and gravity. New checks have been added to ODEPhysics and BulletPhysics.

I also fixed a mistake in one of my earlier PRs, which declared bool ODEPhysics::GetParam to private instead of public.

Jenkins pending

values.description:
We are currently removing the `CMAKE_C_FLAGS_ALL CACHE` and `CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS CACHE` unconditionally. This is a problem when generating debs since we should respect system cflags. For doing that we use `USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS:BOOL=False` (upstream here means our gazebo team).

This PRs allows to keep cflags when asking gazebo not to use the preset of cflags defined by gazebo developers.

The current situation in debian/ubuntu packages is to implement the same using a deb patch. After this PRs this is no longer needed.
values.title: Respect system cflags when not using USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS

summary.raw:
We are currently removing the `CMAKE_C_FLAGS_ALL CACHE` and `CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS CACHE` unconditionally. This is a problem when generating debs since we should respect system cflags. For doing that we use `USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS:BOOL=False` (upstream here means our gazebo team).

This PRs allows to keep cflags when asking gazebo not to use the preset of cflags defined by gazebo developers.

The current situation in debian/ubuntu packages is to implement the same using a deb patch. After this PRs this is no longer needed.
summary.html:
We are currently removing the CMAKE_C_FLAGS_ALL CACHE and CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS CACHE unconditionally. This is a problem when generating debs since we should respect system cflags. For doing that we use USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS:BOOL=False (upstream here means our gazebo team).

This PRs allows to keep cflags when asking gazebo not to use the preset of cflags defined by gazebo developers.

The current situation in debian/ubuntu packages is to implement the same using a deb patch. After this PRs this is no longer needed.

values.description:
This is a backport of pull request #1527 to `gazebo5`. From that pull request:

Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules, but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake. As gazebo only considered the first one, find_package(Gazebo) failed on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.

Thanks to @v4hn for the contribution!
values.title: Backport pull request #1527 (FindOGRE.cmake for non-Debian systems)

summary.raw:

Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules, but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake. As gazebo only considered the first one, find_package(Gazebo) failed on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.

Thanks to @v4hn for the contribution!

Debian moves the cmake files provided by OGRE to /usr/share/OGRE/cmake/modules, but the project itself installs them to /usr/lib/OGRE/cmake. As gazebo only considered the first one, find_package(Gazebo) failed on systems like Lunar-Linux or Arch-Linux.

Thanks to @v4hn for the contribution!

values.description:
We will move to use the ign-math library in Gazebo6. This is the first pull request along this trajectory.

A `libignition-math2-dev` debian is available.

**Things to note**

1. ign-math is now required
1. gazebo math is still available. The internal library will be deprecated in gazebo7, and removed in gazebo8.
1. There will a lot of files that get touched. I'll make many small pull requests, with this one being the largest.
1. Users will be affected. We follow the tick-tock model, so they will have plenty of time to migrate their code. 
    1. A migration tutorial will be created in the near future to help people transition.
    1. Examples will be added, as shown in this pull request.
1. We can also look forward to a migration of gazebo's transport system to ign-transport. 

** New Jenkins Builds**

[Nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/172/)

[No gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/228/)


** Update (05/18) **

1. Updated [Windows install tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/218)
1. New jenkins builds are in the queue
    1. [Homebrew clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/191/)
    1. [Nvidia clean ](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/212//)
    2. [no-gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/277/)
1. This branch compiles and runs on Windows.

**Update (6/3/15)**

1. [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/233/)
1. [No gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/325/)
1. [Nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/249/)
1. Everything still runs on Windows.

** Update (6/8/15)**

1. [No gpu clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/329/)
1. [Nvidia clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/253/)
1. [Homebrew clean](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/237/warnings7Result/new/package.-602053952/)
values.title: First step in transition to ign-math

summary.html:
We will move to use the ign-math library in Gazebo6. This is the first pull request along this trajectory.

A libignition-math2-dev debian is available.

Things to note

  1. ign-math is now required
  2. gazebo math is still available. The internal library will be deprecated in gazebo7, and removed in gazebo8.
  3. There will a lot of files that get touched. I'll make many small pull requests, with this one being the largest.
  4. Users will be affected. We follow the tick-tock model, so they will have plenty of time to migrate their code.
    1. A migration tutorial will be created in the near future to help people transition.
    2. Examples will be added, as shown in this pull request.
  5. We can also look forward to a migration of gazebo's transport system to ign-transport.

New Jenkins Builds

Nvidia

No gpu

Update (05/18)

  1. Updated Windows install tutorial
  2. New jenkins builds are in the queue
    1. Homebrew clean
    2. Nvidia clean
    3. no-gpu clean
  3. This branch compiles and runs on Windows.

Update (6/3/15)

  1. Homebrew
  2. No gpu
  3. Nvidia
  4. Everything still runs on Windows.

Update (6/8/15)

  1. No gpu clean
  2. Nvidia clean
  3. Homebrew clean

values.description:
pull request #1534 presents one approach to integrating the [ignition-math](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math) library into gazebo as an eventual replacement for the `gazebo::math` classes. This pull request presents another approach.

Switching to `ignition-math` will require changes to both gazebo code and downstream gazebo plugin code. It's my understanding that the philosophy of pull request #1534 is to encourage everyone to stop using `gazebo/math/*.hh` header files, `gazebo::math::` classes and helper functions, and start using `ignition-math` instead. This will also require adapting to some API differences between `ignition-math` and `gazebo::math`.

This will be a lot of work/pain. It would be one thing if it was only pain for us, but it will also affect our downstream users who write gazebo plugins using math classes, which is likely almost 100% since math is our lowest-level library. It would actually be even worse for our users, who would need to use `#ifdef`'s if they want their plugin to support multiple versions of gazebo. I have an alternative in this pull request that could reduce the pain of transition for ourselves and our users.

Caveat: I haven't fully implemented it; so it might not work, but I think it's worth discussing. I'm willing to support the approach in pull request #1534, but I'd like this approach to at least be considered.

Approach, focusing only on the `math::Angle` class as an example (see Step 4 for the key idea):

1. Add `ignition-math` as an optional dependency (6df6b70); it will later be required

2. Deprecate `gazebo::math::Angle` functions that don't match the `ignition::math::Angle` API and add replacement functions that do match (9d1c07f)

3. Fix `gazebo::math::Angle` deprecation warnings in gazebo (0558a69)

4. If `ignition-math` is found, typedef `ignition::math::Angle` as `gazebo::math::Angle` and don't compile Angle.cc; this is the key part that could reduce the pain of transition. Users would still be able to include `gazebo/math/Angle.hh` and use `gazebo::math::Angle`, but it would all simply point to `ignition/math/Angle.hh` and `ignition::math::Angle`.

5. Eventually make `ignition-math` required and delete all the `.cc` files in `gazebo/math`.

Other caveats:

1. I had to remove `class Angle` from `gazebo/math/MathTypes.hh` (a6c6ada) because it was causing problems. I'm not sure if this is a big deal or not or if it will be for other math classes.

2. I saw a conflict between something in `gazebo/math/Helpers.hh` and `ignition/math/Helpers.hh`, though I can't remember where I saw it. Hopefully jenkins shows it.
values.title: Integrate ignition-math (alternative to pull request #1534)

Switching to `ignition-math` will require changes to both gazebo code and downstream gazebo plugin code. It's my understanding that the philosophy of pull request #1534 is to encourage everyone to stop using `gazebo/math/*.hh` header files, `gazebo::math::` classes and helper functions, and start using `ignition-math` instead. This will also require adapting to some API differences between `ignition-math` and `gazebo::math`.

This will be a lot of work/pain. It would be one thing if it was only pain for us, but it will also affect our downstream users who write gazebo plugins using math classes, which is likely almost 100% since math is our lowest-level library. It would actually be even worse for our users, who would need to use `#ifdef`'s if they want their plugin to support multiple versions of gazebo. I have an alternative in this pull request that could reduce the pain of transition for ourselves and our users.

Caveat: I haven't fully implemented it; so it might not work, but I think it's worth discussing. I'm willing to support the approach in pull request #1534, but I'd like this approach to at least be considered.

Approach, focusing only on the `math::Angle` class as an example (see Step 4 for the key idea):

1. Add `ignition-math` as an optional dependency (6df6b70); it will later be required

2. Deprecate `gazebo::math::Angle` functions that don't match the `ignition::math::Angle` API and add replacement functions that do match (9d1c07f)

Users would still be able to include `gazebo/math/Angle.hh` and use `gazebo::math::Angle`, but it would all simply point to `ignition/math/Angle.hh` and `ignition::math::Angle`.

Other caveats:

summary.html:
pull request #1534 presents one approach to integrating the ignition-math library into gazebo as an eventual replacement for the gazebo::math classes. This pull request presents another approach.

Switching to ignition-math will require changes to both gazebo code and downstream gazebo plugin code. It's my understanding that the philosophy of pull request #1534 is to encourage everyone to stop using gazebo/math/*.hh header files, gazebo::math:: classes and helper functions, and start using ignition-math instead. This will also require adapting to some API differences between ignition-math and gazebo::math.

This will be a lot of work/pain. It would be one thing if it was only pain for us, but it will also affect our downstream users who write gazebo plugins using math classes, which is likely almost 100% since math is our lowest-level library. It would actually be even worse for our users, who would need to use #ifdef's if they want their plugin to support multiple versions of gazebo. I have an alternative in this pull request that could reduce the pain of transition for ourselves and our users.

Caveat: I haven't fully implemented it; so it might not work, but I think it's worth discussing. I'm willing to support the approach in pull request #1534, but I'd like this approach to at least be considered.

Approach, focusing only on the math::Angle class as an example (see Step 4 for the key idea):

  1. Add ignition-math as an optional dependency (6df6b70); it will later be required

  2. Deprecate gazebo::math::Angle functions that don't match the ignition::math::Angle API and add replacement functions that do match (9d1c07f)

  3. Fix gazebo::math::Angle deprecation warnings in gazebo (0558a69)

  4. If ignition-math is found, typedef ignition::math::Angle as gazebo::math::Angle and don't compile Angle.cc; this is the key part that could reduce the pain of transition. Users would still be able to include gazebo/math/Angle.hh and use gazebo::math::Angle, but it would all simply point to ignition/math/Angle.hh and ignition::math::Angle.

  5. Eventually make ignition-math required and delete all the .cc files in gazebo/math.

Other caveats:

  1. I had to remove class Angle from gazebo/math/MathTypes.hh (a6c6ada) because it was causing problems. I'm not sure if this is a big deal or not or if it will be for other math classes.

  2. I saw a conflict between something in gazebo/math/Helpers.hh and ignition/math/Helpers.hh, though I can't remember where I saw it. Hopefully jenkins shows it.

values.description:
gtest provides a [RecordProperty](https://code.google.com/p/googletest/wiki/V1_6_AdvancedGuide#Logging_Additional_Information) function for logging `int`'s and `std::string`'s to the junit xml file created when running `make test` (when running individual tests manually, you need to supply the [--gtest_output:xml](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/968df3ac24e90b761e3da6bce44b24f49a9e2ff6/cmake/GazeboTestUtils.cmake#cl-44) flag to generate the xml file). This PR provides additional helper functions for recording `double`, `SignalStats`, and `Vector3Stats` types to these xml files. I've also updated a few tests with Record statements to illustrate how it can be used.

I put the new functions in a separate file called `ServerFixtureRecord.cc` since `ServerFixture.cc` is huge. I also provided a ruby tool `junit_to_csv.rb` for converting the junit xml files to csv so they can easily be viewed in a spreadsheet program. ( @\_jrivero_ should I remove the `.rb` suffix from that tool?)
values.title: Add helper functions to ServerFixture for recording data

gtest provides a RecordProperty function for logging int's and std::string's to the junit xml file created when running make test (when running individual tests manually, you need to supply the --gtest_output:xml flag to generate the xml file). This PR provides additional helper functions for recording double, SignalStats, and Vector3Stats types to these xml files. I've also updated a few tests with Record statements to illustrate how it can be used.

I put the new functions in a separate file called ServerFixtureRecord.cc since ServerFixture.cc is huge. I also provided a ruby tool junit_to_csv.rb for converting the junit xml files to csv so they can easily be viewed in a spreadsheet program. values.description: The `INTEGRATION_joint_screw` test is failing for dart because the pr2 has a closed kinematic chain in the gripper, and dart does not yet handle that properly (#1435). This will disable the dart portion of that test until that issue is resolved.

values.description:
This pull request replaces `boost::shared_ptr` with `std::shared_ptr` in the entirety of the Physics library. `boost::dynamic_pointer_cast`, `boost::static_pointer_cast`, and `boost::const_pointer_cast` have also been replaced with their standard library equivalents.

If you `grep` for any of the above keywords in the physics library, you should get no results.

I also had to touch files in `sensor`, `plugin` and the test suite for compatibility with this change. `ServerFixture::CheckPointer`, a `protected` function, has been changed to take a `std::shared_ptr` instead of a `boost::shared_ptr`. (If the `boost::shared_ptr` function should be deprecated instead of deleted, let me know... I figured this change was OK because it's a. in the test library and b. not a public function.)

Looking to the future, `boost::thread`, `boost::mutex`, and `boost::unordered_set/map` are other candidates for conversion to to their standard library equivalents.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/84/)
values.title: Replaced boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in Physics

This pull request replaces `boost::shared_ptr` with `std::shared_ptr` in the entirety of the Physics library. `boost::dynamic_pointer_cast`, `boost::static_pointer_cast`, and `boost::const_pointer_cast` have also been replaced with their standard library equivalents.

If you `grep` for any of the above keywords in the physics library, you should get no results.

I also had to touch files in `sensor`, `plugin` and the test suite for compatibility with this change. `ServerFixture::CheckPointer`, a `protected` function, has been changed to take a `std::shared_ptr` instead of a `boost::shared_ptr`. (If the `boost::shared_ptr` function should be deprecated instead of deleted, let me know... I figured this change was OK because it's a. in the test library and b. not a public function.)

Looking to the future, `boost::thread`, `boost::mutex`, and `boost::unordered_set/map` are other candidates for conversion to to their standard library equivalents.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/84/)
summary.html:
This pull request replaces boost::shared_ptr with std::shared_ptr in the entirety of the Physics library. boost::dynamic_pointer_cast, boost::static_pointer_cast, and boost::const_pointer_cast have also been replaced with their standard library equivalents.

If you grep for any of the above keywords in the physics library, you should get no results.

I also had to touch files in sensor, plugin and the test suite for compatibility with this change. ServerFixture::CheckPointer, a protected function, has been changed to take a std::shared_ptr instead of a boost::shared_ptr. (If the boost::shared_ptr function should be deprecated instead of deleted, let me know... I figured this change was OK because it's a. in the test library and b. not a public function.)

Looking to the future, boost::thread, boost::mutex, and boost::unordered_set/map are other candidates for conversion to to their standard library equivalents.

Jenkins

values.description:
`MainWindow` creates many actions in the function [`CreateActions`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a096fba880dab14bae6b43cab3a1405cd437778f/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=default#cl-924), called in the constructor. This pull request ensures that the destructor of `MainWindow` deletes those actions.

Not deleting the actions was causing a bug in `TimePanel_TEST`. The first test case would create a `MainWindow` then delete it. The next test cases would call the actions created by the previously deleted `MainWindow`, then segfault. My initial workaround was to create new MainWindow objects for each test case, but I realized that `TimePanel` should be able to stand on its own without a `MainWindow` object.

I also added a new test to `MainWindow` to check that the actions get created and destroyed properly. The entire `MainWindow` test won't pass until [PR1502](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1502/delete-scene-on-exit) gets merged, but this case passes on my machine. You can also check that `TimePanel_TEST` passes with this PR.
values.title: Destroy actions created in MainWindow (fixes TimePanel_TEST)

summary.raw:
`MainWindow` creates many actions in the function [`CreateActions`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/a096fba880dab14bae6b43cab3a1405cd437778f/gazebo/gui/MainWindow.cc?at=default#cl-924), called in the constructor. This pull request ensures that the destructor of `MainWindow` deletes those actions.

Not deleting the actions was causing a bug in `TimePanel_TEST`. The first test case would create a `MainWindow` then delete it. The next test cases would call the actions created by the previously deleted `MainWindow`, then segfault. My initial workaround was to create new MainWindow objects for each test case, but I realized that `TimePanel` should be able to stand on its own without a `MainWindow` object.

I also added a new test to `MainWindow` to check that the actions get created and destroyed properly. The entire `MainWindow` test won't pass until [PR1502](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1502/delete-scene-on-exit) gets merged, but this case passes on my machine. You can also check that `TimePanel_TEST` passes with this PR.
summary.html:
MainWindow creates many actions in the function CreateActions, called in the constructor. This pull request ensures that the destructor of MainWindow deletes those actions.

Not deleting the actions was causing a bug in TimePanel_TEST. The first test case would create a MainWindow then delete it. The next test cases would call the actions created by the previously deleted MainWindow, then segfault. My initial workaround was to create new MainWindow objects for each test case, but I realized that TimePanel should be able to stand on its own without a MainWindow object.

I also added a new test to MainWindow to check that the actions get created and destroyed properly. The entire MainWindow test won't pass until PR1502 gets merged, but this case passes on my machine. You can also check that TimePanel_TEST passes with this PR.
